claim: France uses the euro as its official currency

supporting.text: France adopted the euro as its official currency on January 1, 1999, replacing the French franc, as part of the European Monetary Union.

attacks.text: France adopted the euro as its official currency on January 1, 1999, replacing the French franc, as part of the European Monetary Union.
Some regions of France, such as overseas territories, use currencies other than the euro, like the CFP franc.
The CFP franc is pegged to the euro and used only in specific overseas territories, which are a minor exception and do not represent mainland France.
The euro is not universally accepted in all transactions within France, as some small businesses may prefer cash payments in other currencies for tax evasion.
Such practices are illegal and not representative of the official currency policy of France, which strictly enforces the use of the euro.

supporting.text: The euro is the sole legal tender in France, as confirmed by the European Central Bank and French monetary authorities.

attacks.text: The euro is the sole legal tender in France, as confirmed by the European Central Bank and French monetary authorities.
Some overseas territories of France, such as French Polynesia, use the CFP franc instead of the euro.
The CFP franc is pegged to the euro and is not a fully independent currency, so the euro remains the de facto standard.
Historical records show that France used the French franc before adopting the euro in 2002, which contradicts the idea of the euro being the sole legal tender throughout history.
The claim specifies the current official currency, not historical ones, making the historical context irrelevant to the present claim.

supporting.text: All financial transactions, including wages, taxes, and retail purchases, are conducted in euros in France, demonstrating its official status.

attacks.text: All financial transactions, including wages, taxes, and retail purchases, are conducted in euros in France, demonstrating its official status.
Some overseas territories of France, such as French Polynesia, use the CFP franc instead of the euro.
The CFP franc is pegged to the euro and used only in specific overseas territories, while mainland France exclusively uses the euro.
Certain businesses in border regions may accept other currencies like Swiss francs or US dollars for convenience.
Accepting other currencies is optional and not legally mandated, while the euro remains the only official currency for all legal transactions.

supporting.text: France is a founding member of the Eurozone, which mandates the use of the euro as the official currency for all member states.

attacks.text: France is a founding member of the Eurozone, which mandates the use of the euro as the official currency for all member states.
Some regions of France, like the overseas territories, use currencies other than the euro.
The overseas territories are exceptions and not part of metropolitan France, which strictly uses the euro.
Historical records show that France could theoretically leave the Eurozone and revert to the franc, making the euro's status as official currency reversible.
The legal and political barriers to leaving the Eurozone are extremely high, making reversion to the franc practically implausible in the foreseeable future.

supporting.text: French banknotes and coins are denominated in euros, and the franc is no longer in circulation, further confirming the euro's official status.

attacks.text: French banknotes and coins are denominated in euros, and the franc is no longer in circulation, further confirming the euro's official status.
France's overseas territories like French Polynesia and New Caledonia use the CFP franc, not the euro.
The CFP franc is pegged to the euro and used only in specific non-European territories, not mainland France.
Some French businesses unofficially accept francs for nostalgic purposes, creating dual-currency situations.
Such franc acceptance is extremely rare and has no legal standing under European Central Bank regulations.
